results.title: Look again at garden birds
results.creator_credit: Gateway Film Productions, Royal Society for the Protection of Birds and Anthony Clay
results.brief_description: This interesting and informative film looks at the habits and characteristics of most bird species commonly found in gardens throughout the British Isles. Narrated by Eric Thompson.

results.title: Look after your bicycle! [Junior Road Safety Series Episode 3]
results.creator_credit: Martin Williams Films, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Martin Williams, Malcolm Otton and Henry Lewes
results.brief_description: The setting of the film is a bicycle repair shop, presided over by a mechanic who is surrounded by bicycles waiting to be repaired. Direct teaching is avoided by making various parts of the bicycle talk, in children’s voices. They tell the repair man about the treatment they have received from their riders and the accidents and near-misses in which they have been involved. As they talk, scenes show how badly maintained bicycles can be the cause of accidents.

results.title: Look & book: arts & entertainment video directory
results.creator_credit: Raceplay, Irene Krumins, Gary Gray and Ron Cummings
results.brief_description: A video catalogue of forty-five groups and artists who are available to perform at all types of venues including school functions and fetes. A wide range of performers are shown, covering such areas as: magic, mime, clowns, rock, country, folk and bush bands, cabaret, comedy, jazz and blues, guitars, piano and chamber orchestas, puppet theatre, dance and movement, vocal peformance and poetry.

results.title: Lonnie's day
results.brief_description: We become part of Lonnie’s world as we follow him through a typical day - at home in a high rise apartment complex, at school and in the streets of a large city neighbourhood. A sensitive film that shows the stresses, pleasures and family life of an eight year old African American boy.

results.title: Longtime companion
results.creator_credit: Samuel Goldwyn Company, Stan Wlodkowski and Norman Rene
results.brief_description: One of the first American films to deal with the AIDS epidemic, Norman Rene’s ‘Longtime companion’ traces the lives of a group of young American gay men living and dying in the time of AIDS. The film’s starting point is 1980 when the disease is first mentioned in the New York Times. Initially referred to back then as ‘Gay-Related-Immune-Disorder’, the early whispers of a mysterious ‘gay cancer’ hardly rated a mention. Based on a Craig Lucas play, the film documents the rapid spread of the disease throughout the eighties as these once healthy men are suddenly faced with their own mortality. The film and play takes its title from the refusal of the New York Times to acknowledge homosexual partners in their obituary column, preferring the more discreet term ‘longtime companion’. At the time of the film’s release it was criticized for being too discreet in its attempt at dealing with homosexuality and AIDS, and was conservative enough for cast member Bruce Davison to win the most mainstream of accolades, a Best Supporting Actor at the Oscars. The film’s sentimental finale drew the most fire, particularly from a very politicized Queer movement, who saw it as innocuous and conservative (three years later Jonathan Demme’s ‘Philadelphia’ would also draw the same criticism). In retrospect however the film’s tenderness for it’s characters and it’s earnest attempt to chronicle the devastating effect of the epidemic ultimately accumulates an emotional resonance that moves, even in it’s final wish-fulfillment coda. Cast includes: Campbell Scott, Dermot Mulroney, Michael Schoeffling, Mary Louise Parker.

results.title: Long weekend
results.brief_description: A young couple decide to spend a long weekend away in the bush together in an attempt to save their failing marriage. They head for a beach so isolated that even the locals have not heard of it. Strange things begin to happen, including the disappearance of their dog and then the girl herself. Cast includes John Hargreaves and Briony Behets.

results.title: Long way to the top: stories of Australian rock & roll
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Greg Appel
results.brief_description: Compiled from the ABC-TV documentary series, “Long way to the top” is an in-depth visual and musical exploration of the cultural and creative explosion created by the arrival of the raucous, untameable voice of youth, otherwise known as rock and roll. Spanning the period 1956-2000 over six episodes, the series celebrates the evolution and re-interpretation of popular music and youth culture in Australia in the second half of the twentieth century. Not only a salute to Australian and New Zealand rock acts that achieved fame, this ‘rockumentary’ series also looks at the voices that struggled to be heard - the influence of the music of subcultures such as the hippies, punk, grunge and dance bands and the effect they have had in creating unique local sounds. Featured acts include: Johnny O’Keffe, Col Joye, Little Pattie, The Deltones, Billy Thorpe and the Aztecs, The Masters Apprentices, The Easybeats, The Seekers, Chain, Daddy Cool, AC/DC, Hush, Skyhooks, Rose Tattoo, The Angels, INXS, The Birthday Party, Midnight Oil, The Saints, The Models, Divinyls, Mental as Anything, Men at Work, Paul Kelly, Kylie Minogue, Nick Cave, Warumpi Band, The Cruel Sea and Silverchair. This version contains 1 hour extra material not seen in the original broadcast series. A comprehensive companion website to the series can be found at http://abc.net.au/longway/

results.title: Long Way to the Top – AC/DC
results.credit_line: ℗ 1976 J. Albert & Sons Pty Ltd. (Young / Scott / Young)
results.brief_description: The music video for AC/DC’s hit that featured the ban travelling down Melbourne’s Swanston street on the back of a truck, which helped lead to the band having a laneway named after them.

constellations_primary.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_primary.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

results.description: Countdown (1974–87) was not only one of the first television programs in the world to regularly play music videos, but it also created clips for local acts such as It’s A Long Way To The Top (1976) for AC/DC. The footage of the band travelling down Melbourne’s Swanston Street on the back of a truck as they perform live became so iconic, it led to the city naming a key piece of geography after them in 2004: ACDC Lane.
description_for_label: Countdown (1974–87) was not only one of the first television programs in the world to regularly play music videos, but it also created clips for local acts such as It’s A Long Way To The Top (1976) for AC/DC. The footage of the band travelling down Melbourne’s Swanston Street on the back of a truck as they perform live became so iconic, it led to the city naming a key piece of geography after them in 2004: ACDC Lane.
